ARABIC: يَدْعُوا۟ لَمَن ضَرُّهُۥٓ أَقْرَبُ مِن نَّفْعِهِۦ لَبِئْسَ ٱلْمَوْلَىٰ وَلَبِئْسَ ٱلْعَشِيرُ

ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_0: He calls on what is far more likely to harm than help. What an evil protector! What an evil associate!
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_1: They pray to him whose bane is more imminent than his boon: How bad the protector and how bad the associate!
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_2: He invokes those that are more likely to cause him harm than benefit. Such is surely an evil patron, and an evil associate.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_3: Their worship of such things, in which there is no hope for any benefit, can only harm them. How terrible is such a guardian and companion!
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_4: They worship one from whom harm is expected more than the benefit; indeed what an evil master and indeed what an evil friend!
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_5: He calls unto him whose harm is nearer than his profit; certainly an evil Mawla and certainly an evil `Ashir!
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_6: He calls upon him whose harm is nearer than his profit; evil certainly is the guardian and evil certainly is the associate.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_7: He calls upon him who is likelier to hurt him, rather than to profit him -- an evil protector indeed, he, an evil friend!
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_8: He calleth unto him whose harm is nearer than his benefit; verily an evil patron and verily an evil friend!
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_9: he calls on that which would sooner harm than help. Such a patron is indeed evil and such a companion is indeed evil.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_10: He calleth upon him whose hurt is nearer than his profit: surely ill the patron! ill the comrade!
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_11: He invokes someone whose harm is surely likelier than his benefit. An evil ally indeed, and an evil companion!
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_12: (Perhaps) they call on one whose hurt is nearer than his profit: evil, indeed, is the patron, and evil the companion (or help)!
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_13: He calls unto him whose harm is nearer than his profit; certainly, and evil Maula (patron) and certainly an evil friend!
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_14: He calls upon him whose harm is nearer than his benefit, an evil guide and an evil friend.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_15: He invokes one whose harm is closer than his benefit. What a miserable master. What a miserable companion.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_16: He invokes one whose harm is closer than his benefit - how wretched the protector and how wretched the associate.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_17: [22:13] He calls on him (the lām [of la-man] is extra) whose harm, when worshipped, is likelier than his benefit, even if he were to have any benefit, as he imagines [him to have]. Truly an evil patron, is he, that is, [an evil] helper, and an evil friend, [an evil] companion is he. After the mention of ‘the doubter’ and [his being in manifest] ‘loss’ [above, verse 11] there follows [the mention of] the believers and [their] reward, as follows:
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_18: (He calleth unto) the Banu'l-Hallaf worship (him whose harm is nearer than his benefit) his harm is near while his benefit is far; (verily an evil patron) an evil lord (and verily an evil friend!) He says: it is truly an evil god him whose worship is harmful.
